thread.title: Nordstrom's Stock Goes Up After President Trump Goes After Them On Twitter
thread.title_full: Nordstrom's Stock Goes Up After President Trump Goes After Them On Twitter

author: Cosmopolitan.com
title: Nordstrom's Stock Goes Up After President Trump Goes After Them On Twitter
text:
President Donald Trump just unintentionally gave a tiny boost to our country's economy — and he's likely not going to be happy when he hears why.
My daughter Ivanka has been treated so unfairly by @Nordstrom . She is a great person -- always pushing me to do the right thing! Terrible!
— Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) February 8, 2017 Advertisement - Continue Reading Below After Nordstrom announced that they were discontinuing carrying Ivanka Trump's clothing and jewelry brand in their stores due to poor sales, the president took to Twitter on Wednesday to condemn the brand for treating his daughter "so unfairly."
"My daughter Ivanka has been treated so unfairly by Nordstrom," he wrote. "She is a great person — always pushing me to do the right thing! Terrible!"
But rather than inspire people to boycott the brand, his Twitter attack instead caused the brand's stock to surge. According to People , "Nordstrom stock barely flinched at President Trump’s criticism, dipping less than 1% before aggressively reversing course, ending the day up more than 4%."
This is in contrast to other brands Trump has targeted on Twitter, which saw their stocks plummet after being attacked by the president online — and has caused some to speculate that investors are now viewing the stock market as a means of protest.
The #Trump Protest, now on Wall Street.
Traders "rebelled" against Trump's tweet in attempt to hurt the share price of $JWN pic.twitter.com/pckGDN98Fe
— The Daytrade™ (@d4ytrad3) February 8, 2017 However, People goes on to point out it's possible that Nordstrom saw a surge in stock after Trump's tweet at least in part by coincidence: Shortly after the president fired off the tweet, the National Retail Federation released its annual forecast, which suggested Nordstrom would have a successful 2017.
Advertisement - Continue Reading Below Nonetheless, the surge suggests that a Trump tweet doesn't hold quite the same financial sway that it has in the past, and that investors are continuing business as usual despite the president's opinions.
Follow Gina on Twitter .
